text:
When youâ€™ve got one of the most watched, impactful and passionate players in the game â€” you celebrate.

This week, Nike World Headquarters is all things Caitlin Clark and send ups to her new logo as a Nike signature athlete. That Caitlin Energy extends to worldwide, motivating and empowering the next generation of hoopers.

â€œAt Nike, weâ€™ve always drawn inspiration not only from the worldâ€™s greatest athletes but also from those who elevate the spirit of sport itself. Caitlin exemplifies both: an exceptional basketball player and an outstanding ambassador for the game,â€ says Ann Miller, EVP, Nike Global Sports Marketing.

Find out more about how Caitlin and Nike are shaping the future of womenâ€™s basketball: https://lnkd.in/gvWTKvUE

comments.author: Andre Kolak
comments.subtitle: Student at Stony Brook University
comments.text:
You "celebrate" the individual athlete to obscure the exploitation of the millions! You elevate one woman to a logo, to a brand, to distract from the alienated labor of the countless unnamed workers who produce the very commodities upon which her "iconicity" is built.

This "Caitlin Energy" you commodify is not her own; it is the spirit of mass culture appropriated by capital. You speak of "empowering the next generation," yet this is merely the reproduction of the same ideological apparatus: convincing young women that their liberation lies not in collective struggle, but in the individualistic pursuit of becoming a branded athlete for Nike.

Her exceptional athletic power is real, but you convert it into surplus value. Her influence is genuine, but you harness it to sell shoes. You do not elevate the spirit of sport; you subjugate it to the law of value.

The true "future of women's basketball" will not be shaped by a logo, but by the players seizing the means of productionâ€”claiming ownership of their leagues, their likeness, and the value their collective labor generates.

This is not empowerment. It is the spectacle. You offer the image of revolution while reinforcing the tyranny of capital.

Therefore, theyâ€™ll be using a lot of creativity and inspiration and following some social themes such as: environment protection, a safe world, save the ocean, no guns, every life matters, anti racismÂ themes, the right for education, more peace no war, a sustainable world, ... comments.author: Empower Beauty By Rishika
comments.subtitle: 111 followers
comments.text:
As a brand built by and for the disability community, this line gave us pause.

â€œRamp sprints between meetingsâ€ might sound like a fun quip, but for many of us, ramps arenâ€™t fitness challenges. Theyâ€™re lifelines.

Weâ€™re all for energy, innovation, and movement, but we also believe language should move us toward greater inclusion. Accessibility isnâ€™t a punchline or a performance metric. Itâ€™s a right. And when companies as influential as Nike speak, the world listens.

Weâ€™d love to see a future where all athletes, creators, and professionalsâ€”disabled and non-disabledâ€”feel seen, respected, and supported in spaces like this.

text:
For almost 50 years, Nikeâ€™s made magic by taking the most basic of elements â€” air â€” and optimizing it to help athletes perform at their peak. Now, the companyâ€™s hit a new milestone in innovation, this time in materials: Nike Radical AirFlow, debuted in this summerâ€™s trail running season. 

Building on a rich legacy in performance apparel, Nike scientists, designers and developers asked how they could create apparel that harnesses air around a runner in motion to help keep them cool. 

"We were interested in a material that could accelerate the velocity of airflow to skin and help speed up that evaporative cooling process,â€ says Jahan Behbahany, Senior Director, Nike Apparel Innovation.Â "We knew we had the people, the tools and the resources to develop it."

Go behind Nikeâ€™s newest material innovation: https://lnkd.in/ghaUe9H5

comments.subtitle: Sr.3D Virtual Knitwear Designer | Shima Seiki Programmer | Expert in Sweater Simulation & APEX | Tech-Pack to Production. Labib group. Email: mdrakibul.dumki@gmail.com WhatsApp : +8801747179328
comments.text:
Apex 3D by Shima Seiki is a game-changer for the sweater industry.
It helps to reduce sampling costs, save production time, and ensure accurate virtual prototyping before going to bulk production. With Apex 3D, designers and buyers can visualize the final garment in realistic form, make instant modifications, and approve styles without physical samples. This not only improves communication with buyers but also supports sustainable fashion by minimizing material waste.

In the sweater department, where creativity, speed, and precision are essential, Apex 3D ensures efficiency, reduces lead time, and adds significant value to the supply chain.

text:
For our 2025 interns, the summer at NIKE, Inc. ended with a sprint to the finish.

That finish line was marked by the day each intern completed and presented their individual project to Nike leadership. It was the moment when months of innovation and hustle came together â€” and the 2025 class delivered.

â€œThe interns of this year were incredible to see â€” defining a new â€˜gold standardâ€™ for what it looks like to be at Nike,â€ Â says Andrew Roddam, Director, Supply Chain Innovation. â€œInterns this year came with a critical-thinking lens to focus on big problems, all while using their unique styles to propose solutions. I was especially impressed with seeing how they brought their stories to life, using great storytelling to drive their point home.â€

Next summer, it could be you. Explore opportunities: https://lnkd.in/gwmt4NzK

text:
Empowering athletes through information. That goal is at the heart of NSRL Form, the Nike Sport Research Labâ€™s latest movement-analysis tool. Itâ€™s not just a runnerâ€™s tool. Itâ€™s a running tool, designed to study your whole body in motion, giving you the self-awareness you need in order to become a more efficient runner. 
 
As the track and field world descends on Tokyo, the newly opened Nike Harajuku will debut NSRL Form to our Japanese athletes, helping them understand their one-of-one running profiles.Â Chikanori Kawaguchi, Nikeâ€™s first ever retail Running Professional and based in Nike Harajuku, will lead the NSRL Form service and bring the insights of the Nike Sport Research LabÂ to the local area.
 
"In Japan, running is not just a sport, but a way of life,â€ says Kawaguchi. â€œItâ€™s only right that Nike serves our runners here through premium product and services like NSRL Form. Itâ€™s a privilege to be able to do this. As an avid runner myself, Iâ€™m excited to help Japanâ€™s runners better know themselves.â€
 
Go inside NSRL Form: https://lnkd.in/g9yfa2c6

comments.author: Higgs Boson Consultancy Ltd.

comments.text: Still hire human, why not AI? Our AI-powered development can double up your development efficiency. Professional development price only start from 120 pounds/ day, and full refund if it doesn't meet your requirements and standards.

comments.author: Andre Kolak
comments.subtitle: Student at Stony Brook University
comments.text:
This isn't empowerment, it's the ideology of capital. You mythologize "the grind" to mask exploitation. "Silence that voice" means ignore your own exhaustion and alienated labor. "Your limits are an illusion" denies the material reality of wages and burnout. This isn't a call to mastery, but to self-domination for profit. True liberation isn't found in the grind, but in rejecting it.

#GlitchTheGrind

comments.text:
From lab to retail: NSRL Form is a strong step to transform data into real self-awareness. ğŸ‘ŸğŸ“Š

Next-level proposal:
â€¢ Combine 2D capture + inertial sensors to segment each stride phase (landingâ€“midstanceâ€“toe-off). 
â€¢ Build a â€œRunner Passport 1/1â€: a unique profile linking footstrike, cadence, stiffnessâ€”with drills and shoe recommendations. 
â€¢ Integrate prevention and â€œreturn-to-runâ€ protocols for post-injury athletes.

This way, every runner not only measures but sees visible, personalized progress. Congrats on bringing motion science to Harajuku, Japan. ğŸ‡¯ğŸ‡µ

comments.text: Jana B. thank you for sharing this post amazing information! :D

text:
And thatâ€™s a wrap in Tokyo. For the last week and a half, the Japan National Stadium has hosted 60,000-strong sell-out crowds as the globeâ€™s best track and field athletes competed for the title of World Champion. Whether you sat in the stands or watched from home, Japanâ€™s devoted fandom for the sport was undeniable.

That energy carried through the newly opened doors of Nike Harajuku, as fans arrived inspired by the championship meet. In the middle of the action was Shiraishi Tomoki, Director of Retail Marketing, Japan, who worked tirelessly to prepare for Nike Harajukuâ€™s opening on September 11, right before the meet began. Whether he was helping develop the storeâ€™s communication plan or perfecting the storeâ€™s Nike By You experience, Tomoki-san was in the middle of the action.

The effort was well worth the work, says Tomoki-san. He called the store opening his favorite Nike moment. The camaraderie he felt with his teammates as they created an unforgettable experience for track fans proved that a project like this really does take an entire village.

â€œIt wasnâ€™t just about opening a store,â€ says Tomoki-san. â€œIt was about setting a moment to create energy and excitement for the brand. We all saw the responsibility we had in making this the best experience possible for our visitors. Whenever you work on a project with your teammates here, you know that youâ€™re working with like-minded people, doing whatever it takes to create something special.â€

Relive the energy in Tokyo at https://lnkd.in/gSe7B_kK
